children.subject: I've literally never heard of anyone getting $300k+... or is this a troll post

history.content: A lot of HFT (high frequency trading) firms tend to give out a lot for new grads. Not necessarily $300k + but the total comp can most definitely get very close to $300k. New grads at big firms like Jane Street, HRT, and TS can definitely make that much. However, I would strongly advise you to not take a job just because it pays extremely high. At such a young age, you have the ability to take a lot of risks so it might be better to go for what you like (and may probably be good at) even if it pays a tad bit less. Most of the high paying new grad jobs are quantitative in nature (some are swe at these firms) but this means that not only is the competition for these jobs extremely high but you must be very high performing even when you get it (aka, one strike and you're out).

Even top new grad offers in the industry at like FB or so aren't that high for a yearly comp. Maybe wall street might hit that with bonuses but you trade your soul

children.subject: Wallstreet/trading/hftanalysis etc is a lot of work. Have a friend working in that type of job and she works from 6am to 8 or 9 pm Monday through Friday. She is getting out in under 2 years though and is just doing it for the cash.
wdym trade your soul? is working at wall street that horrible? Can you elaborate.

I know people working at the firms mentioned as new grads and noone is making 300k+ annually (not including signing bonus). In fact I don't think barring extreme exceptions any companies will be paying that much for new grads.
Not heard of $300K+ but you can generally hit a "total comp" of around $200K if you factor in base salary + stock options + signing bonus.
wow you have lucky friends. I would guarantee you that 300k+ salaries are outliers even for schools like Berkeley, MIT, Stanford...
Jeez, I thought my $150k was already pretty good...

history.content: I hear so many people getting $300k+ offers as a new grad.. How in the world are you guys getting this kinds of offers? Obviously you must be doing something other than the run-of-the-mill 4.0 GPA or honors club. Please help some fellow bears out.
history.subject: How are new grads getting $300k+ offers?
